b. That the network office undertake to publish a
dittoed report, similar to the executive director’s policy
letters, at periodic intervals for the purpose of fully
informing members of the board and other interested individuals
on all network developments.
c. That the problem of program acceptance be given
immediate attention and that a decision be made on precisely
who shall have the final power to approve and/or reject
programs.
d. That all final arrangements for programs and all
committments of the network’s facilities be made through this
office. Further, that before negotiations have advanced to
the final stage all potential sources of programs be put in
touch with this office to coordinate details before the
final product is prepared.
e. That all gifts, contributions, etc. made to the
network be handled through this office. The financial
structure within the University’s business office provides
two funds allowing for a good deal of flexibility. At the
same time it makes all accounts a matter of public record
*€(ncfr efficient accounting. It seems clear that central financial
control is the only sound business practice.
f. That Seymour Siegel and Jim Miles get together and
establish a sound and practical relationship between WNYC and
the network. That it be clarified what is obtained for the
network, and what for the station. That a policy be
established whereby the network could pay the recording costs
on certain programs desired—where they are acquired primarily
for the network.
It is obvious that New York will always be a source of
many programs. It is equally obvious that WNYC is the natural
obtainer of these programs. Therefore, a practical arrangement
whereby the network gets these programs on a basis other than
at the convenience of WNYC seems mandatory.
None of this is intended to disparage the enormous
contributions of WNYC to the network. I know that we here
and all the stations as well feel the deepest gratitude for
the many fine programs supplied the network by the New York
station. It is purely the mechanics of the process which
seem to me to be on axis an unorganized, helter-skelter basis.
I assume we can expect some programs of WNYC origin on the
same basis that we receive them from other stations. It is
not fair to expect this station to bear added costs and
troubles to get things for the network in volume far in excess
of the load expected from other stations. On the other
hand it does not seem wise to be without an organized
understanding as to how this process should work.
